Risks to the Builder:

| Subclause | Risk |
| --- | --- |
| 21.1 | Failure to provide timely notice of practical completion may result in delay in receiving payment and/or liability for damages arising from the delay |
| 21.2 | Failure to accurately assess practical completion date may result in a dispute with the owner |
| 21.3(a) | Failure to complete the works to a satisfactory standard may result in the owner withholding payment |
| 21.3(b) | Additional work required to reach practical completion may result in delays and additional costs to the builder |
| 21.5(i) | Dispute resolution process may result in further delays and costs for the builder |
| 21.5(ii) | Suspension of work during dispute resolution process may result in further delays and costs for the builder |
| 21.6 | Non-payment of final progress claim may result in the builder pursuing legal action against the owner for debt recovery |

Risks to the Owner:

| Subclause | Risk |
| --- | --- |
| 21.1 | Failure to receive timely notice of practical completion may result in delay in arranging an inspection |
| 21.2 | Dispute with builder over practical completion date may result in delay in arranging an inspection |
| 21.3(a) | Paying final progress claim before the work is complete may result in defects being overlooked |
| 21.3(b) | Dispute with builder over additional work required to reach practical completion may result in delays |
| 21.5(i) | Dispute resolution process may result in further delays and costs for the owner |
| 21.5(ii) | Suspension of work during dispute resolution process may result in further delays and costs for the owner |
| 21.6 | Non-payment of final progress claim may result in legal action being taken against the owner for debt recovery |

Note: These tables are not exhaustive and do not account for all possible risks or benefits. They are intended as a brief summary of some of the most significant risks and benefits associated with each subclause of clause 21.

Building a new home or renovating an existing one can be a thrilling experience for homeowners. However, the construction process can also be challenging, especially when it comes to understanding the legal terms and conditions in the building contract. One of the most critical stages of a construction project is Practical Completion, as it marks the end of the construction phase and the start of the handover process. Understanding what Practical Completion means, when it is achieved, and the associated legal obligations and risks is essential for homeowners under the HIA Contract. In this guide, we will provide a comprehensive overview of Practical Completion under the HIA Contract, including the definition of Practical Completion, the difference between Practical Completion and Final Completion, the timeframe for achieving Practical Completion, and the legal implications of receiving a Notice of Practical Completion under Clause 21 of the HIA Contract.
Write me the “II. The HIA Contract” part of the article in less than 200 words.

The HIA (Housing Industry Association) is a leading industry body in the Australian residential building sector. The HIA provides a range of model contracts, including the HIA Standard Form of Contract for Housing and Residential Works, which is widely used in the industry. This contract regulates the relationship between the builder and the homeowner, outlining their rights, obligations, and liabilities. It is important for homeowners to understand the terms and clauses of the contract before signing it, as it will govern the construction process and the parties' rights and obligations throughout the project. One of the most critical clauses for homeowners to understand is Clause 21, which sets out the requirements for Practical Completion of the works. This clause is fundamental to determining when the builder has completed the works and when the homeowner must pay the final payment. Understanding this clause is crucial to managing the risks and ensuring a successful project outcome.
